dataset.title: A Metadata-Based Framework for Multilingual Ecological Information Management

abstract.para: Herein, we introduce a framework of an ecological information management prototype of tools based on a metadata standard. The framework was developed by the Ecological Informatics Working Group of the Taiwan Forestry Research Institute (TFRI) to aid with editing, storing, and using documents in the multiple languages of Asian cultures that comprise the East-Asia Pacific International Long-Term Ecological Research (EAP-ILTER) Network. The conceptual framework of the system can be divided into three tiers. The first tier deals with datasets and related information. The second tier relates to information management. Once datasets and other related information have been described, they are stored in a schema-independent database. The third tier is comprised of the full web-based interfaces that allow easy access to the second tier. Results of the application of this framework consist of an Ecological Metadata Language (EML) document database module, a data analysis function module, and a collection of 58 EML documents.

section.title: develop a metadata-base framwork
section.para: The first step in developing and testing the conceptual framework was to review the resources available in the field of ecoinformatics. After conducting this review, we decided to adopt the systems developed by the National Center for Ecological Analysis and Synthesis (NCEAS) at the University of California, Santa Barbara which include Morpho, Metacat (short for â€œmetadata catalogâ€), and the EML2R from the Processing Techniques for Automated Harmonization (PTAH) project at the University of Virginia. Jointly these provide the tools for creating, editing, storing, retrieving, and using EML documents. Then Morpho and Metacat were modified to resolve language coding issues in Asian countries including China, Japan, Korea, Malaysia, Mongolia, the Philippines, Taiwan, and Thailand. Finally, the system was tested through workshops held domestically and internationally.
